content: Sculpture in Singapore The **Elephant statue**, also known as the **Thai Elephant**, is a bronze sculpture in front of [The Arts House](/wiki/The_Arts_House) along High Street of the [Downtown Core](/wiki/Downtown_Core) area in Singapore. ## History The statue was erected in front of the [Victoria Memorial Hall](/wiki/Victoria_Memorial_Hall) on 25 June 1872 as a gift by King [Chulalongkorn](/wiki/Chulalongkorn) of Thailand to commemorate his 1871 visit to [Singapore in the Straits Settlements](/wiki/Singapore_in_the_Straits_Settlements). The statue was cast in bronze in [Bangkok](/wiki/Bangkok), and was mounted on a large pedestal. The inscriptions on the pedestal, which are in [English](/wiki/English_language), [Chinese](/wiki/Chinese_language), [Siamese](/wiki/Central_Thai_language), and [Jawi](/wiki/Jawi_dialect), read, "His Majesty Somdetch Paramindr Maha Chulalongkorn, the Supreme King of Siam, landed at Singapore, the first foreign land visited by a Siamese Monarch, on the 16th March, 1871". ## See more - [National Museum of Indonesia](/wiki/National_Museum_of_Indonesia), where located another elephant statue of the King in [Indonesia](/wiki/Indonesia) 1°17′19″N 103°51′03.6″E﻿ / ﻿1.28861°N 103.851000°E﻿ / 1.28861; 103.851000 This article about a Singapore building or structure is a stub. You can help Wikipedia by expanding it. - v - t - e
title: Elephant statue
